What you're saying is that there are phenomena(stuff that happens) and mechanisms(explanations for phenomena) and whether we credit a given mechanism or not, we must certainly credit the phenomenon itself. Thus, a certain murder may be unsolved, but there is no doubt of the murder itself. Somebody certainly got whacked, we just don't know for certain how or by whom. 
 
 In the case of evolution, we can go further than that. Not only is evolution certainly true, but natural selection also is certainly true. It is also a phenomenon which in turn is certainly part of the mechanism of the phenomenon evolution. There is very little doubt that natural selection is one of the factors that drives evolutionary change What Darwin proposed is three things 1) Evolution happens 2) Natural Selection happens 3) Natural selection is the EXCLUSIVE mechanism of evolution, it is not just one of the factors but the sole driving force of evolution. He showed how all three ideas are very plausible when one examines the evidence. The evidence was rather limited in his own time, but it has grown since then to the point that no-one who knows what he is talking about seriously doubts 1) or 2) above. 3) is more problematic. While most evolution can be explained as driven by natural evolution, that in certain eras may have been driven by other factors, sudden cataclysms like asteroid strikes and volcanoes, and even tendentious and cumulative(rather than random) genetic mutations in certain conditions. There is no real consensus here among scientists but wherever there is doubt there are very reasonable mechanistic theories which provide explanations, merely that they have not been clearly established to be true. Any grounds for evoking superstitious nonsense to explain away some anamoly in the evolutionary timeline have long ago completely disappeared.

This is seriously the best, succinct explanation of evolution vs natural selection I've ever seen, as well as a brilliantly put explanation of why evolution, in general, cannot be denied. Fantastic work by the folks at minute labs.

Evolution is change.

Natural selection is not the process in which things evolve.

Natural selection is what happens following the evolution of an organism. Natural selection is a byproduct of that change.

Natural selection is when an organism changes and then lives or dies before its genes is passed on.

Evolution and natural selection are not equal and the same. They are separate ideas.

The theory of evolution states that life changes.

The theory of natural selection states the method in which life has changed.

The theory of evolution states that humans were not always human.

The theory of natural selection says that we come from apes in a linear fashion.

The theory of evolution is pretty much in order.

The theory of natural selection is still undergoing major upheavals every few years with the discovery of extremely weird things that make the suggestion that we did NOT come from apes, but may actually be a mix of many different species that crossed over millions of years to include apes.

The theory of natural selection is incomplete. With theories that apes may have crossed with pigs to create humans being just as viable to humans coming straight from apes due to LACK OF UNIFORM LINEAR PROGRESSION OF REMAINS, we cannot know for sure.

We all know that life changes. However, we do not know HOW it has changed for sure quite yet.

This is why the word THEORY accompanies evolution and natural selection. The weakness comes from the fact that we have not yet found a single uniform linear progression of any species on Earth. The theory calls for linear progression. However, what lines of evolution we do find is crossed with so many different species that we sometimes loop back on ourselves and wonder if there might be an error in our data.

I am not saying that we should stop studying evolutionary theory. I am just saying that it IS NOT COMPLETE, and we should STOP ACTING LIKE IT IS.

THEORY is a FACT SUPPORTED GUESS.

The theory of natural selection does not take into account the possibility that a species disappears simply by having it interbreed with a close species. Not all genes are removed by death alone. This sort of thing is happening TODAY in Australia with the interbreeding of domestic dogs and dingos. Dingos are now an endangered species that will soon "die out" without actually "dying out."

See?

The theory is incomplete. If I see any of you out there accusing my of being a creationist, you are an indoctrinated ass who does not know the difference between hypothesis and fact; with no critical thinking or reading comprehension skills.

Supported Theory ≠ Empirical Fact

First off, I loved the irony of the statement "which is stupidly well supported by evidence." I can't help smiling every time I hear it (~1:18). Secondly, the presenter did an admirable job delineating between evolution and natural selection. Well done. Unfortunately, he didn't have time to drill down into the changes that occur under the heading of natural selection. These changes are most familiar to me as macro- and micro-evolution. The former encompasses variations allowed within the already existing genetic code, the latter with changes to the code that bring about a new variation.
The first, macro-evolution, is well documented and fairly straight forward. It has sometimes been mistaken, however, for micro-evolution. The second, micro-evolution, has never been reliably demonstrated. I know I may get heated response on that one, but please keep them civil. I will cheerfully respond to any posts that remain that way and ignore flamers and such, as they are not looking for a reasoned answer, anyway.
If you really want to get to the basics of the argument (basic does not necessarily mean simple), get into the information theory side of the argument. Our blueprints (yes, I gave myself away on that one, you probably saw it coming) are our DNA. Headlines recently proclaimed that it is even more complicated than we knew, with a deeper, secondary code embedded with the primary, still incredibly complex, sequence.
I don't pretend to understand all the science involved, I don't think any one man does, but I have learned to trust in the preponderance of evidence, which, to many, points to the impossibility of life "evolving" (much less arising) due to genetic "improvements." Even if some sort of genetic "seed" was supplied from outside our biosphere (kid you not, people get in serious discussions about the possibility), that just brings up further absurdities.
While you may consider God an absurdity, that is a discussion for another time.

For once I disagree with the video. Evolution of stars and galaxies as well as the evolution of complex systems (e.g. the weather) is also determined by natural selection.

Natural selection just means that the system changed to be at a "better" configuration under the forces that affect it. Biological organism show this by reproduction/replication, where each new generation represents a new stage of change in the adaptation process. In a similar way non biological systems tend towards stable configurations in response to external forces (e.g. gravity, temperature). In both cases the evolution is driven by a natural selection towards a "better" configuration.

What is "better" then? That depends on the system. From the gene point of view, an organism is better when it can survive long enough to replicate its genes. A star is in a better configuration when its mass is such so that it can attract itself (not exploding) and not too high such that it collapses.

On both cases where changes that do not favor "better" configurations the system will simply change in a different direction causing an evolutionary oscillation. If the system is able capable to "recover" (e.g. the changes required to cope with the forces affecting it are too large) it will fall into chaos and acquire a new configuration. For biological systems, death/extinction is also configuration in relation to its environment.

I don't agree.  If i want to say change, i say change.  Is there something wrong with the word "change"?
When people say "Evolution" it is almost always used as a merely shortened form of saying "The theory of evolution by natural selection".

The only time Evolution meant "change" in common parlance, was pre-Darwin.  Before then it merely referred to the OBSERVATION (in fossil evidence etc) that life was changing over time.  But after Darwin, it was clear that this was the correct theory to explain the observation of Evolution, thus in common parlance "Evolution" started to mean nothing other than "The theory of evolution by natural selection" and the 2 things became synonymous in common language - meaning both the observations and the satisfatory theory that explains it, the 2 being rarely required to be separated in common conversation.

It's similar to Gravity (the Theory) and Gravitation (the Observation).  Lay-people rarely ever mention Gravitation, but people talk about Gravity all the time.
Likewise it is with the dual meaning of "Evolution", people rarely refer to the pure observation of Evolution - separate to any theory explaining it.

My favourite evidence of natural selection is that of vestigial structures in people and animals.

Why do whales have a pelvis in its "hip" and finger bones in its fin when fish do not even though they occupy the same habitat? Are believers in creationism not the slightest bit curious why?

What about the appendix, tail bone, and wisdom teeth in humans?

If you Google the ultrasound image comparisons of developing fetuses of different animals vs humans, the similarities are so startling that it is almost impossible for anyone to NOT deduce that we at some point in history shared a common ancestor.

I also want to correct a common misconception people have of evolution and natural selection. We DO NOT evolve during our lifespans. If food is only located in tall trees, we do NOT grow taller to get it. Instead, it is assumed that those who were already born taller as a result of a chance genetic mutation would subsequently be more healthy having better access to said food, and due to sexual selection, be more successful at mating and thus having more offspring who also exhibit the similar "tall" gene, and so on and so on until the new feature is so distinct and prominent that they can no longer be classified as belonging to that of the original species. This process takes millions of years and resulted in what we call giraffes.

This is an excellent video, but I do think using evolution in the way you do isn't quite appropriate.

The evolution of the species is different from the Challenger in that the former is not a "thing" in any ordinary sense.

 Instead a species is just a collection of things which can reproduce with one another. It is this reproduction that makes natural selection work, not the evolution of something which was weakly defined to begin with.

Any collection of objects which reproduces imperfectly and which is selectively culled will show a change in the individuals which make up that collection over time. That change is termed "evolution".

The key fact is that nothing is, strictly speaking, evolving here. A species is just a grouping of individuals into scientifically useful categories, or in this case, categories which are useful for explaining the changes (at a group level) in the individuals which are extant at any one time.

Darwin's natural selection was disproven (more than once) and replaced with Modern Evolutionary Synthesis. Specifically, mutations are not rare events. Organisms inherit characteristics form other than their parents (think viruses). And new species "evolve" through genetic drift, not (solely) through survival of the fittest.  These are all serious modifications of Darwin's theories.

This is the silliest minutephysics I've ever seen. It contains actual flaws in reasoning, an unnecessary bit of invective, and no content, much less coherency. It doesn't even pretend to understand the arguments it implies it is rejecting.

It is, indeed, a triumph of deconstruction - which is to say, it's totally busted.

The flaw in the reasoning initially derives from the especially pauce definition of "evolution" you seem to want to impose. It's nearly impossible to support the idea that the challenger "evolved" into particles: you've eviscerated a key component of the idea by (mis)using the term like that. Part of the definition of evolution is "the gradual development of something, esp. from a simple to a more complex form." The latter is the key idea. Otherwise, you could just as well use the term 'devolve' to mean the same thing as 'evolve', but they are precisely opposite. And, I'll mention here that, as a theory, 'devolution' is vastly more supported by science (entropy?).

That which is predicated on bad definitions seem to be the realm of the political, not the scientific: whether it's misstatements about evolution, or the creation of the universe, or anything bordering on the authentically unexplainable, there is a very large impetus - largely due to cognitive-dissonance and narcissism - to extend the material principles to where they cannot and can never go.

Now, to walk the ignorant/implied criticism part of this episode back, the myriad of people on the "anti-evolution" side that know what they are talking about, first and foremost, take issue with the ateleology of genetic natural selection, which is fundamentally - that is to say, in principle - unsupportable, and, beyond that, insufficiently born out by the evidence to support the claims.

Gradualism was what Darwin was proposing (explicitly rejecting punctuated equilibrium) and vociferously - like any other narcissistic pain in the ass - defending the bad parts about. He was being vociferously argued against on multiple grounds from multiple directions, but you'll note that gradualism is especially rejected from the theory today (given the evidence), which indeed calls the fundamental processes proposed by him into question. Heck, we've seen scientific results in the past few weeks (rat-babies inheriting fear of a given smell from their father) that suggest Lamarck was way more right than anybody for the past 100 years has suspected or granted credence.

The concepts in this video are based on the presupposition that the age of fossils can be determined by the age of rock. The problem with this supposition is that geologists have no way of determining the age of rock other than by utilizing fossils and assuming that all organisms of a particular type appeared or disappeared simultaneously rather than, for example, migrated from one part of the world to another. Layers in rock can tell us what geological events happened and the order in which they happened, but not when they happened. Also, even if we could determine for certain when something lived, it does not mean that one organism changed into another.

In its most general sense, "evolution" does just mean "change over time". However, there's a sense of the word that's more specific than that, yet more general than the evolution of life by natural selection. Essentially, "change driven by competition over generations with variation" is the descriptor for that definition. The thing is, that kind of evolution requires relatively vague circumstances to be all but guaranteed. Below, I'm using this definition when I say "evolution".

/beginLecture

Evolution requires three things: reproduction, mutation, and competition. In biological evolution, reproduction is, well, reproduction of DNA/RNA and the organisms they code for. But in general, reproduction just means "copying". Something needs to be copied from one generation to the next; that can be DNA, or it can be a product's blueprints, or a program's code, or (more abstractly) an idea's foundations. Anything can be copied in any way to satisfy this requirement.

Secondly, you need mutation. In biology, this occurs when the genes are copied imperfectly, leading to changes in base pairs, be they substitutions, deletions, or duplications. This is usually random, but in general, it doesn't have to be. For example, with product design or technology, changes from one version to another are often intentionally made in one direction or another; these are still valid mutations. In genetic programming, Gaussian random mutations are usually used, but again, they may be guided. As long as the copies can change from their parents, mutation is achieved.

Lastly, you need competition. This is a VERY vague term, and all it means is that the chances of an individual reproducing depends upon the mutations it has. In biology, any mutation that allows an organism to reproduce more--often, but not exclusively, because it allows the organism to survive longer, giving it time to reproduce--will be beneficial and be selected for. Any mutations that reduce the chances of reproduction will be selected against. In product design, the competition is based on consumer demand: if a new version has a change that buyers don't want, it's less likely to be reproduced in the next version. Conversely, if a new version's change is favorable, it'll be more likely to stick around in the next version. With genetic programming, property values that get the solution closer to optimal carry over into the next generation, and those that don't get discarded and don't reproduce.

I've gone into detail of each requirement, but overall, the process of evolution is quite simple and vague. Any time anything can (1) copy itself in any way, (2) change from one copy to the next, and (3) be more or less likely to copy itself depending on those changes, evolution of this type WILL happen. It's almost guaranteed. The thing that's evolving can be a population of living creatures, a computer program, a culture and its ideals, technology, or anything else with those three properties. As a tangential note, there's a hypothesis that certain types of black holes might contain entire universes inside them, with differing physical constants. If this is true, then even universes themselves would evolve towards optimal physical constants: each black hole can reproduce (since its contained universe also contains black holes), mutate (since the internal universes have different constants), and compete (since these differing constants would change the rate at which each internal universe produces newer black holes). Intriguing, isn't it? :D

/endLecture

TL;DR: If something, anything, can reproduce, mutate, and compete, then it will almost certainly evolve; whether it's alive, dead, inanimate, unconscious, or anything else doesn't matter.

The contention is whether mutations provide an adequate mechanism to account for all of genetic information we have.
